Citation: Wan, L., Yan, A., O’Doherty, C., Jiang, X., & Hardin, R. (2024). Classic kaposi sarcoma: A comprehensive case report on multisite involvements and therapeutic strategies. Cureus. https://doi.org/10.7759/cureus.52553
Summary:: Classic Kaposi Sarcoma (CKS) is a rare type of cancer, less common than other varieties of Kaposi Sarcoma (KS). This study examines an 83-year-old man with CKS who had lesions on his foot, arm, and thigh, highlighting the difficulties in detecting and treating CKS in various body locations. Kaposi Sarcoma is more typically associated with those with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV/AIDS. Classic Kaposi Sarcoma, on the other hand, is more likely to affect people with normal immune systems.

Citation: Gupta, R., DeBord, L., & Dao, H. (2019). Failed treatment of classic Kaposi’s sarcoma with topical timolol: Case report and review of the literature. Cureus. https://doi.org/10.7759/cureus.6272
Summary:: The study investigates the use of topical timolol, a β-adrenergic receptor antagonist, in treating Classic Kaposi’s Sarcoma (CKS), a localized cutaneous neoplasm. While previous reports showed positive outcomes in eight CKS patients, the study reports a case where 0.5% topical timolol failed to treat the condition over 12 weeks. This suggests that while topical timolol may be a potentially effective and safe alternative for CKS, further prospective studies are needed to understand its overall efficacy and safety.

Citation: Sehitoglu, I., Bedir, R., Cure, E., Cure, M. C., Yuce, S., & Dilek, N. (2016). Evaluation of the relationship between c-kit expression and mean platelet volume in classic Kaposi’s sarcoma. Anais Brasileiros de Dermatologia, 91(4), 430–435. https://doi.org/10.1590/abd1806-4841.20164331
Summary:: The study investigates c-Kit expression in patients with Classic Kaposi's Sarcoma (CKS), finding high positivity linked to increased risk of tumor growth and relapse. c-Kit is a proto-oncogene that encodes a tyrosine kinase receptor, and this study also reveals a positive correlation between c-Kit expression and mean platelet volume (MPV), suggesting that c-Kit and high MPV levels may indicate heightened invasion and relapse risk in KS patients.

Citation: Chen, S.-N., Lin, M.-H., Liao, Y.-H., Liau, J.-Y., Chu, C.-Y., & Sheen, Y.-S. (2023). Anatomic mapping of acral melanocytic Nevi and acral lentiginous melanomas among Taiwanese patients: A retrospective cohort study. Journal of the Formosan Medical Association. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jfma.2023.10.015
Summary:: The study focuses on acral lentiginous melanoma (ALM), which can be confused with a mole (acral melanocytic nevus or AMN). The researchers looked at where these lesions appeared on the palms and soles of Taiwanese patients. They found that ALMs, especially on the soles, were often related to areas under mechanical stress.

Citation: Simonds, R. M., Segal, R. J., & Sharma, A. (2018). Extramammary Paget’s disease: A review of the literature. International Journal of Dermatology, 58(8), 871–879. https://doi.org/10.1111/ijd.14328
Summary:: Extramammary Paget's disease (EMPD) is a rare type of skin cancer that mainly affects older people. This cancer often shows up in the genital and perianal areas and might be linked to other cancers in nearby organs. This study highlights the difficulties in identifying and managing this condition, the need of rigorous diagnostic methods, and the need for long-term follow-up to detect potential consequences and recurrences.

Citation: Mamic, M., Manojlovic, L., Suton, P., & Luksic, I. (2018). Microcystic adnexal carcinoma—diagnostic criteria and therapeutic methods: Case report and review of the literature. International Journal of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery, 47(10), 1258–1262. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijom.2018.03.001
Summary:: The study describes a case of Microcystic Adnexal Carcinoma (MAC), a rare and locally aggressive skin tumor with origins in both the hair follicles and sweat glands, It typically manifests on the upper lip or face.  The study emphasizes the importance of careful histopathological examination for accurate diagnosis, with immunohistochemistry being a helpful tool.

Citation: Durack, A., Gran, S., Gardiner, M. D., Jain, A., Craythorne, E., Proby, C. M., Marsden, J., Harwood, C. A., Matin, R. N., Affleck, A., Ahmed, A., Akhtar, A., Atkar, R., Bisarya, K., Chinthapalli, S., Chowdry, M., Coelho, R., Fawzy, M., Hanna‐Bashara, L., … Wright, B. E. (2020). A 10‐year review of Surgical Management of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans*. British Journal of Dermatology, 184(4), 731–739. https://doi.org/10.1111/bjd.19346
Summary:: The study investigates the surgical management of a rare skin cancer called Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans (DFSP). The standard treatments are wide local excision (WLE) or Mohs micrographic surgery (MMS), and the study aims to determine which approach has a lower recurrence rate. The retrospective review analyzes the surgical management of 483 primary and 64 recurrent DFSP cases in multiple departments.

Citation: Holman, D. M., King, J. B., White, A., Singh, S. D., & Lichtenfeld, J. L. (2023). Acral lentiginous melanoma incidence by sex, race, ethnicity, and stage in the United States, 2010–2019. Preventive Medicine, 175, 107692. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ypmed.2023.107692
Summary:: This study addresses Acral Lentiginous Melanoma (ALM? and focuses on analyzing ALM incidence rates relative to other malignant melanomas It utilizes data from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the National Cancer Institute covering 99% of the U.S. population from 2010 to 2019. The findings underscore the need for awareness of ALM across all races and ethnicities, emphasizing its rarity while acknowledging the potential development of other melanoma types in minority groups. This balanced perspective is crucial for healthcare practitioners and public health strategies to enhance early detection and management of melanomas across diverse populations.

Citation: Basurto‐Lozada, P., Molina‐Aguilar, C., Castaneda‐Garcia, C., Vázquez‐Cruz, M. E., Garcia‐Salinas, O. I., Álvarez‐Cano, A., Martínez‐Said, H., Roldán‐Marín, R., Adams, D. J., Possik, P. A., & Robles‐Espinoza, C. D. (2020). Acral lentiginous melanoma: Basic facts, biological characteristics and research perspectives of an understudied disease. Pigment Cell & Melanoma Research, 34(1), 59–71. https://doi.org/10.1111/pcmr.12885
Summary:: This study aims to contribute to a better understanding of this specific subtype of melanoma, considering its distinct characteristics and potential avenues for targeted therapeutic interventions by providing an overview of current knowledge regarding the etiology and diagnostic criteria of ALM and exploring the epidemiological and histopathological characteristics of the disease, shedding light on its unique features. Additionally, the study delves into the genomic drivers of ALM, an aspect that has been comparatively less explored, and discusses available biological models for investigating potential therapeutic targets.

Citation: Kitamura, S., Yanagi, T., Maeda, T., & Ujiie, H. (2021). Cyclin‐dependent kinase 4/6 inhibitors suppress tumor growth in extramammary Paget’s disease. Cancer Science, 113(2), 802–807. https://doi.org/10.1111/cas.15234
Summary:: This study is about finding potential treatments for Extramammary Paget's Disease (EMPD) and looks at two drugs, abemaciclib and palbociclib, which are known to be effective against a type of breast cancer. The researchers tested these drugs on mice with EMPD-like tumors grown from patient samples. The results showed that both drugs significantly slowed down the growth of these tumors. Additionally, when they looked at samples from real EMPD patients, they found higher levels of certain proteins in the tumor cells compared to normal skin. This suggests that these drugs, known as CDK4/6 inhibitors, could be promising new treatments for EMPD.

Citation: Bayan, C. ‐A. Y., Khanna, T., Rotemberg, V., Samie, F. H., & Zeitouni, N. C. (2018). A review of non‐invasive imaging in Extramammary Paget’s disease. Journal of the European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology, 32(11), 1862–1873. https://doi.org/10.1111/jdv.15072
Summary:: This study explores ways to better diagnose and manage Extramammary Paget's Disease (EMPD) and focuses on non-invasive imaging tools that can help detect and diagnose EMPD early on. These tools include PET/CT scans, reflectance confocal microscopy (RCM), photodynamic diagnosis (PDD), dermoscopy, MRI, and optical coherence tomography (OCT). The study also discusses the use of PET/CT and MRI to detect the spread of the disease to other parts of the body.

Citation: Gambichler, T., Hartenstein, I., Dreißigacker, M., Stockfleth, E., Stücker, M., Schaller, J., Schulze, H. ‐J., Becker, J. C., Käfferlein, H. U., Brüning, T., & Lang, K. (2021). Expression of hedgehog signalling molecules in microcystic adnexal carcinoma. Clinical and Experimental Dermatology, 46(6), 1052–1057. https://doi.org/10.1111/ced.14634
Summary:: This study investigates Microcystic Adnexal Carcinoma (MAC) and aims to understand its molecular characteristics. The researchers specifically look at the expression of certain molecules involved in the Hedgehog signaling pathway, which is known to play a role in some types of skin tumors. They compare the expression of these molecules in MAC to other skin tumors (syringoma, trichoepithelioma, and basal cell carcinoma) to see if there are any differences.

Citation: Moya‐Martínez, C., Torre‐Castro, J., Mendoza‐Cembranos, D., Santonja, C., & Requena, L. (2020). Microcystic adnexal carcinoma with germinative follicular differentiation. Journal of Cutaneous Pathology, 48(1), 123–127. https://doi.org/10.1111/cup.13869
Summary:: The researchers describe a case where the cancer cells in MAC show characteristics resembling the cells found in hair follicles. To support this observation, they used a technique that identifies specific proteins in tissues. The results indicate that certain proteins associated with hair follicle development are present in the cancerous cells of MAC. This suggests a potential connection between MAC and the formation of hair follicles, providing valuable insights into the nature of this type of cancer.

Citation: Peng, C., Jian, X., Xie, Y., Li, L., Ouyang, J., Tang, L., Zhang, X., Su, J., Zhao, S., Liu, H., Yin, M., Wu, D., Wan, M., Xie, L., & Chen, X. (2022). Genomic alterations of dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans revealed by whole‐Genome Sequencing. British Journal of Dermatology, 186(6), 997–1009. https://doi.org/10.1111/bjd.20976
Summary:: This study aims to understand the genetic makeup of Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans (DFSP). The researchers discovered a pattern of mutations in the DNA that is linked to the replication process and found low mutation levels in tumors that tend to recur. The researchers also found structural abnormalities in specific chromosomes, leading to the amplification of cancer-promoting genes or the deletion of tumor-suppressing genes.

Citation: Baumann, J. R., Groneck, A. D., & Martin, K. L. (2023). Skin cancer: Back to basics. Journal of the Dermatology Nurses’ Association, 15(4), 190–195. https://doi.org/10.1097/jdn.0000000000000746
Summary:: This study is a review of Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans (DFSP) which is known for its slow growth and often appears as a plaque on the trunk of young adults, resembling a scar. The article provides an overview of the epidemiology, pathophysiology, clinical features, diagnosis methods, staging, and treatment options for DFSP. The aim is to increase awareness among healthcare providers about this uncommon form of skin cancer, ultimately improving patient outcomes by facilitating early diagnosis and appropriate management.

Citation: Zaggana, E., Konstantinou, M. P., Krasagakis, G. H., de Bree, E., Kalpakis, K., Mavroudis, D., & Krasagakis, K. (2022). Merkel Cell Carcinoma-Update on Diagnosis, Management and Future Perspectives. Cancers, 15(1), 103. https://doi.org/10.3390/cancers15010103
Summary:: This paper was published a little over a year ago and provided some updates in the form of a literature review. The paper specifically talked about how immunotherapy has been a prominent form of treatment for this cancer. The method of immunotherapy currently being used is anti-PD-1/PD L1 blockade but is only effective as a first line of treatment due to the cancer's ability to quickly acquire resistance.

Citation: Starrett, G. J., Thakuria, M., Chen, T., Marcelus, C., Cheng, J., Nomburg, J., Thorner, A. R., Slevin, M. K., Powers, W., Burns, R. T., Perry, C., Piris, A., Kuo, F. C., Rabinowits, G., Giobbie-Hurder, A., MacConaill, L. E., & DeCaprio, J. A. (2020). Clinical and molecular characterization of virus-positive and virus-negative Merkel cell carcinoma. Genome medicine, 12(1), 30. https://doi.org/10.1186/s13073-020-00727-4
Summary:: The majority of literature after an initial search indicates that Merkel cell carcinoma arises due to UV damage in Merkel cells. This paper talks about how there is an alternative pathway for obtaining this cancer, which is through the integration of Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV) and the expression of viral T antigens. Furthermore, the paper presents a study in which deep sequencing is employed to determine if the viral pathway is present as opposed to the UV damage pathway.

Citation: Becker, J. C., Stang, A., DeCaprio, J. A., Cerroni, L., Lebbé, C., Veness, M., & Nghiem, P. (2017). Merkel cell carcinoma. Nature reviews. Disease primers, 3, 17077. https://doi.org/10.1038/nrdp.2017.77
Summary:: This paper serves as a literature review that explains what Merkel Cell Carcinoma is as well as current information regarding how it is diagnosed and treated. This paper provides some helpful visuals for understanding how the disease arises.

Citation: Takagawa, Y., Tamaki, W., Suzuki, S., Inaba, K., Murakami, N., Takahashi, K., Igaki, H., Nakayama, Y., Shigematsu, N., & Itami, J. (2019). Radiotherapy for localized sebaceous carcinoma of the eyelid: a retrospective analysis of 83 patients. Journal of radiation research, 60(5), 622–629. https://doi.org/10.1093/jrr/rrz046
Summary:: This paper talks about a retrospective study regarding radiotherapy for the treatment of subcutaneous carcinoma of the eyelid. The other common method of treatment is through surgical removal of the main tumor. This study supports that for even very large sebaceous tumors (>10 mm).

Citation: Lee, S. H., Jung, Y. H., Yoo, J. Y., & Park, H. J. (2018). A Case Report of Recurrent Metastatic Sebaceous Carcinoma Which Showed Favorable Response Tt Non-Fluorouracil Based Chemotherapy. The American journal of case reports, 19, 1192–1196. https://doi.org/10.12659/AJCR.912552
Summary:: This paper talks about a case study in which systemic sebaceous carcinoma is treated with non-fluorouracil chemotherapy. Given that this sort of cancer rarely metastasized, the researchers were surprised to see that this treatment was effective. I would likely need to learn more about the differences between regular chemotherapy and non-fluorouracil therapy to understand the impact.

Citation: Dasgupta, T., Wilson, L. D., & Yu, J. B. (2009). A retrospective review of 1349 cases of sebaceous carcinoma. Cancer, 115(1), 158–165. https://doi.org/10.1002/cncr.23952
Summary:: In general, there are very few large-scale literature reviews for this type of carcinoma. The purpose of this paper was to determine who is primarily affected by the disease. It was found that the majority of the cases were amongst white individuals. This paper serves for a good foundation of understanding the details of the cancer itself.

Citation: Nyeko, R., Geriga, F., Angom, R., & Kambugu, J. B. (2022). Oral-visceral iatrogenic Kaposi sarcoma following treatment for acute lymphoblastic leukemia: a case report and review of the literature. Journal of medical case reports, 16(1), 405. https://doi.org/10.1186/s13256-022-03620-3
Summary:: A variation of KS can arise as an aftermath of transplants, chemotherapy, or other procedures that result in immunosuppression. This paper is about a case study in which after being treated for leukemia, an individual has developed KS orally. The KS was successfully treated with two well-known drugs, bleomycin and vincristine.

Citation: Yaqub, S., Stepenaskie, S. A., Farshami, F. J., Sibbitt, W. L., Jr, Fangtham, M., Emil, N. S., & Bankhurst, A. D. (2019). Kaposi Sarcoma as a Cutaneous Vasculitis Mimic: Diagnosis and Treatment. The Journal of clinical and aesthetic dermatology, 12(11), 23–26.
Summary:: This paper emphasizes how within a case study of an elderly woman, all signs pointed to lesions on the surface of the skin being resistant to vasulitis. Eventually, it was discovered that KS was the true diagnosis and acted as a pseudo-vasculitis. As the disease progressed, further immunosuppression occurred.

Citation: Alsaidan, M. S., Aljarbou, O. Z., & Alajroush, W. (2023). Kaposi Sarcoma in a Child after Fanconi Anemia-Induced Haploidentical Hematopoietic Stem Cell Transplant: A Case Report. Children (Basel, Switzerland), 10(2), 188. https://doi.org/10.3390/children10020188
Summary:: This case study presents a child who has developed KS after having a stem cell transplant. KS can frequently occur in individuals who have who organs transplanted, but very rarely in cases such as stem cell transplantation. The KS eventually diminished without metastasis.

Citation: Cao, J., Wang, J., He, C., & Fang, M. (2019). Angiosarcoma: a review of diagnosis and current treatment. American journal of cancer research, 9(11), 2303–2313.
Summary:: This paper discusses the basics of Angiosarcoma, which is technically not a skin cancer but is often confused with skin cancers as the first sign of malignancy appears on the surface of the skin. It talks about how the cancer is so aggressive since it originated int he lining of blood vessels, commonly near the skin. By having close access to the blood stream, the cancer can easily metastasize compared to other cutaneous cancers.

Citation: Gaballah, A. H., Jensen, C. T., Palmquist, S., Pickhardt, P. J., Duran, A., Broering, G., & Elsayes, K. M. (2017). Angiosarcoma: clinical and imaging features from head to toe. The British journal of radiology, 90(1075), 20170039. https://doi.org/10.1259/bjr.20170039
Summary:: This paper talks about how these tumors tend to appear on imagining. There are many images that can be useful when presenting this disease to someone such as a physician majority of angiosarcoma cases appear on the surface of the head or neck. Other common instances are found on the surface of the breasts, genitals, or even buttocks.

Citation: Ishida, Y., Otsuka, A., & Kabashima, K. (2018). Cutaneous angiosarcoma: update on biology and latest treatment. Current opinion in oncology, 30(2), 107–112. https://doi.org/10.1097/CCO.0000000000000427
Summary:: While many papers dive into the basics of angiosarcoma as a whole, this paper goes into detail about cutaneous angiosarcoma specifically. This would be a more helpful resource for our platform in particular. The paper discusses the typical prognoses and lines of treatment for an individual with cAS.

Citation: Yde, S. S., Sjoegren, P., Heje, M., & Stolle, L. B. (2018). Mucosal Melanoma: a Literature Review. Current oncology reports, 20(3), 28. https://doi.org/10.1007/s11912-018-0675-0
Summary:: Despite melanoma being the most common type of skin cancer, mucosal melanoma is the rarest of these cancers, affecting less than 1% of those with melanoma. This cancer in particular arises from mucosal linings as opposed to cutaneous origin. This paper serves as a good foundation for basics of the cancer.

Citation: Ma, Y., Xia, R., Ma, X., Judson-Torres, R. L., & Zeng, H. (2021). Mucosal Melanoma: Pathological Evolution, Pathway Dependency and Targeted Therapy. Frontiers in oncology, 11, 702287. https://doi.org/10.3389/fonc.2021.702287
Summary:: This paper talks about the disease as a whole as well as the therapies and outcomes associated with it. While this cancer can appear in a mucosal lining within the body, the most favorable prognosis is amongst those found in the mouth or throat. While surgery is the first line of defence, other targeted therapies such as radiation and immunotherapy are discussed in this paper.

Citation: Hintzsche, J. D., Gorden, N. T., Amato, C. M., Kim, J., Wuensch, K. E., Robinson, S. E., Applegate, A. J., Couts, K. L., Medina, T. M., Wells, K. R., Wisell, J. A., McCarter, M. D., Box, N. F., Shellman, Y. G., Gonzalez, R. C., Lewis, K. D., Tentler, J. J., Tan, A. C., & Robinson, W. A. (2017). Whole-exome sequencing identifies recurrent SF3B1 R625 mutation and comutation of NF1 and KIT in mucosal melanoma. Melanoma research, 27(3), 189–199. https://doi.org/10.1097/CMR.0000000000000345
Summary:: This paper describes a study in which those with mucosal melanoma had their DNA sequences to determine which gene mutations were associated with this specific cancer. By recognizing these genes, therapies can be employed to target those mechanisms associated with the genes. This can also help in diagnosing those potentially with Mucosal Melanoma.

Citation: Toro JR, Beaty M, Sorbara L, et al. γδ T-Cell Lymphoma of the Skin: A Clinical, Microscopic, and Molecular Study. Arch Dermatol. 2000;136(8):1024–1032. doi:10.1001/archderm.136.8.1024
Summary:: The paper serves to help understand the clinical, microscopic, and molecular methods of cutaneous T-cell Lymphoma through understanding EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus). In their conclusion they found that there is a clonal T-Cell receptor chain gene that was rearranged in all 3 of the cases that they study and that they were all negative for EBV. As such, they determiend that Cutaneous T-Cell lymphomas are not related to EBV and that they have an aggressive clinical behavior along with a mature cytotoxic phenotype.

Citation: Kempf, W., & Mitteldorf, C. (2021). Cutaneous t‐cell lymphomas—an update 2021. Hematological Oncology, 39(S1), 46–51. https://doi.org/10.1002/hon.2850
Summary:: This article provides an update from 2021 on Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphomas. It gives context to which disoders (Mycosis Fungoides ((MF)) and cutaneous CD30+ lymphorpoliferative disoders) account for the most diagnosised Cutaneous T-Cell Lymphomas. Along with that it discusses the treatments and other considerations that need to be thought about when diagnosis this condition.

Citation: Kim-James, H. Y., & Heffernan, M. P. (2001). The diagnosis, evaluation, and treatment of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. Current Problems in Dermatology, 13(6), 301–340. https://doi.org/10.1067/mdm.2001.119860
Summary:: This paper provides an overview of how common the disease is, basic demographic, and the sources. Along with that it gives a basic overview of Cutaneous T-Cell lymphomas and how to diagnosis it. It also let's us know that there is no known cure, but that there are treatments that the cancer response to.

Citation: McGarvey, Megan E. BA; Tulpule, Anil MD; Cai, Jie MD; Zheng, Tong DDS; Masood, Rizwan PhD; Espina, Byron AB; Arora, Naveen PhD; Smith, D. Lynne PhD; Gill, Parkash S. MD. Emerging treatments for epidemic (AIDS-related) Kaposi's sarcoma. Current Opinion in Oncology 10(5):p 413-421, September 1998.
Summary:: This paper talks about the treatments for epidemic Kaposi's sarcoma. It goes through how they decide who should be treated wwith what type of treatment. Along with that it also talks about people with advanced diseases and what they are treated with. It also talks about risk factors and identifying those in terms of who should be treated for KS.

Citation: ARMSTRONG AW, LAM KH, CHASE EP. Epidemiology of classic and AIDS-related Kaposi’s sarcoma in the USA: incidence, survival, and geographical distribution from 1975 to 2005. Epidemiology and Infection. 2013;141(1):200-206. doi:10.1017/S0950268812000325
Summary:: This paper talks about where KS is most frequented in terms of geography along with that it also talks about how it's the second most frequent tumor in HIV-infected patients. Along with that it talks about the KS lesions are describes them in detail. It also talks about treatments including getting treatment for HIV first and then treating the infection.

Citation: Séverin, Davida; Bessaoud, Faizac,∗; Meftah, Nadiad; Du Thanh, Aureliea; Tretarre, Brigittec; Guillot, Bernarda; Makinson, Alainb. A comparative study of classic and HIV-viremic and aviremic AIDS Kaposi sarcoma. AIDS 35(3):p 399-405, March 1, 2021. | DOI: 10.1097/QAD.0000000000002744
Summary:: The papers objective is describe KS occuring in people living with HIV as it's the msot common AIDS-assocaited amlignancy. They wanted to understand the context of clinical presentations through the Aviral and viral AIDS-KS and classic KS. Through this they learned that viremic AIDS-KS has more aggressive presentation and that there is a similar presentation between controlled viremia and Class KS.

Citation: Brooks J, Ramsey ML. Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans. [Updated 2023 Apr 14]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK513305/#
Summary:: DFSP is a rare skin cancer that grows slowly from deep within your skin and can spread around but doesn't usually go farther than that. It pops up mostly in adults, and no one's really sure what causes it, but it might have something to do with your genes getting mixed up. The go-to move for dealing with it is cutting it out because it tends to come back if not totally removed.

Citation: Hao X, Billings SD, Wu F, Stultz TW, Procop GW, Mirkin G, Vidimos AT. Dermatofibrosarcoma Protuberans: Update on the Diagnosis and Treatment. J Clin Med. 2020 Jun 5;9(6):1752. doi: 10.3390/jcm9061752. PMID: 32516921; PMCID: PMC7355835.
Summary:: This article is basically about scientists looking closely at the genes involved in DFSP to figure out better ways to spot it and treat it. They're hopeful that by understanding the genetic side of things, they can come up with treatments that are right on target.

Citation: Lyu A, Wang Q. Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans: A clinical analysis. Oncol Lett. 2018 Aug;16(2):1855-1862. doi: 10.3892/ol.2018.8802. Epub 2018 May 24. PMID: 30008876; PMCID: PMC6036409.
Summary:: This talks about DFSP, looking at how it behaves, how well treatments work, and what the chances are for patients to get better. They found out that catching it early and getting surgery can really help patients. Their work gives doctors new insights on how to better help folks dealing with DFSP.

Citation: Bishop BN, Lynch DT. Kaposi Sarcoma. [Updated 2023 Jun 5]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK534839/
Summary:: this article talks about a type of cancer that forms in the skin and can spread to other organs. It talks about how it's linked to a virus and is more common in people with weakened immune systems. The piece also covers symptoms, diagnosis methods, and treatment options, showing the importance of early detection and management.

Citation: Cesarman E, Damania B, Krown SE, Martin J, Bower M, Whitby D. Kaposi sarcoma. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2019 Jan 31;5(1):9. doi: 10.1038/s41572-019-0060-9. PMID: 30705286; PMCID: PMC6685213.
Summary:: this paper talks about a cancer that shows up mainly on the skin but can affect other parts of the body too. It's tied to a virus and often pops up in people with weaker immune systems. Citation: Schneider JW, Dittmer DP. Diagnosis and Treatment of Kaposi Sarcoma. Am J Clin Dermatol. 2017 Aug;18(4):529-539. doi: 10.1007/s40257-017-0270-4. PMID: 28324233; PMCID: PMC5509489.

Summary:: This review consolidates knowledge on MAC, covering its epidemiology, clinical behavior, and treatment options, aiming to enhance patient management and outcomes.

Citation: Zaggana E, Konstantinou MP, Krasagakis GH, de Bree E, Kalpakis K, Mavroudis D, Krasagakis K. Merkel Cell Carcinoma-Update on Diagnosis, Management and Future Perspectives. Cancers (Basel). 2022 Dec 23;15(1):103. doi: 10.3390/cancers15010103. PMID: 36612102; PMCID: PMC9817518.
Summary:: This paper talks about the diagnosis, treatment, and future research. It outlines the disease's aggressiveness and treatment challenges, emphasizing the need for early detection and advanced therapeutic strategies.

Citation: Becker JC, Stang A, DeCaprio JA, Cerroni L, Lebbé C, Veness M, Nghiem P. Merkel cell carcinoma. Nat Rev Dis Primers. 2017 Oct 26;3:17077. doi: 10.1038/nrdp.2017.77. PMID: 29072302; PMCID: PMC6054450.
Summary:: This article talks about how to spot it, and the latest ways to fight it. It talks about how much this cancer can affect people and why zeroing in with specific treatments matters. It's all about getting a clearer picture of MCC and what makes it tick.

Summary:: This article talks about the tricky nature of T-cell lymphomas, covering the various types, how they're treated, and what might happen in the future. The goal is to give you a better understanding of T-cell lymphomas, from how they're diagnosed to potential improvements in treatment.

Summary:: This study is a comprehensive overview of Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC), a rare and aggressive form of skin cancer. It discusses various aspects of MCC including its epidemiology, risk factors, clinical presentation, diagnostic methods, staging, and treatment options.

Citation: Sundqvist, B., Sihto, H., von Willebrand, M., Böhling, T., & Koljonen, V. (2021). LRIG1 is a positive prognostic marker in Merkel cell carcinoma and Merkel cell carcinoma expresses epithelial stem cell markers. Virchows Archiv, 479(6), 1197–1207. https://doi.org/10.1007/s00428-021-03158-7
Summary:: This study investigates the expression of certain markers associated with hair follicle and epidermal stem cells in Merkel cell carcinoma (MCC) and normal human skin. The researchers aim to explore the possibility that a subset of MCC tumors may originate from epithelial stem cells of the skin. They specifically examine the expression of CK19, SOX9, LGR5, and LRIG1 through immunohistochemistry and correlate these expression patterns with various clinicopathological characteristics, including patient survival and Merkel cell polyomavirus (MCPyV) status.

Citation: Kim, D. W., Lee, G., Lam, M. B., Harris, E. J., Lam, A. C., Thomas, T., Chau, N. G., & Tishler, R. B. (2020). Advances in Radiation Oncology, 5(2), 301–310. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.adro.2019.11.008
Summary:: This study presents a case report of a 73-year-old man with an extensive microcystic adnexal carcinoma (MAC) lesion on his philtrum, a region between the nose and upper lip. The patient had initially refused surgical resection of the MAC nodule, which had been present for 12 years. He presented with worsening symptoms including upper lip numbness, midfacial swelling, and nose firmness over the course of a year.

Citation: Saal, R. C., Bauer, B. D., Pariser, R. J., & Smith, M. K. (2023). Hair repigmentation in microcystic adnexal carcinoma. JAAD Case Reports, 35, 84–86. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jdcr.2023.03.008
Summary:: This study reports a case of hair repigmentation surrounding a microcystic adnexal carcinoma (MAC) of the scalp in a 74-year-old man. Hair repigmentation of previously nonpigmented hairs is a phenomenon that has been observed in various conditions, including drug reactions and underlying pathologies. The patient presented with a 1-year history of an indurated, scar-like, flat depression on the right side of the midline scalp, surrounded by dark hairs.

Citation: Lidenge, S. J., Tso, F. Y., Ngalamika, O., Kolape, J., Ngowi, J. R., Mwaiselage, J., Wood, C., & West, J. T. (2020). Lack of CD8+ T-cell co-localization with Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus infected cells in Kaposi’s sarcoma tumors. Oncotarget, 11(17), 1556–1572. https://doi.org/10.18632/oncotarget.27569
Summary:: This study investigates the role of tumor infiltrating immune cells (TIIC) in Kaposi's sarcoma (KS) pathogenesis, particularly in the context of HIV-1 co-infection. Kaposi's sarcoma is closely associated with immune dysfunction, but it remains unclear whether TIIC, their absence, presence, or dysfunction, are mechanistically correlated with KS development. Additionally, it's uncertain whether TIIC could serve as prognostic biomarkers for KS disease progression or control. The study focuses on comparing TIIC between two forms of KS: epidemic-KS (EpKS), which occurs in individuals co-infected with HIV-1, and HIV-negative African endemic-KS (EnKS). This comparison aims to dissect the roles of HIV-1 and Kaposi Sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) in KS pathogenesis.

Citation: Chung, W.-C., Lee, S., Kim, Y., Seo, J. B., & Song, M. J. (2021). Kaposi’s sarcoma-associated herpesvirus processivity factor (PF-8) recruits cellular E3 ubiquitin ligase CHFR to promote PARP1 degradation and lytic replication. PLOS Pathogens, 17(1). https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.ppat.1009261
Summary:: This study focuses on the role of Poly(ADP-ribose) polymerase 1 (PARP1) in the control of Kaposi's sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV) lytic replication. KSHV is a virus that can establish latent infections in host cells, and periodic reactivation of the virus is necessary to maintain its population within cells. The inhibition of KSHV lytic replication is crucial for controlling viral infection and preventing tumorigenesis. PARP1 is a nuclear enzyme involved in various cellular processes, including the DNA damage response, cell death, chromatin remodeling, transcription regulation, inflammation, and tumorigenesis. This study investigates the relationship between PARP1 and KSHV lytic replication.

Citation: Dickson, B. C., Hornick, J. L., Fletcher, C. D., Demicco, E. G., Howarth, D. J., Swanson, D., Zhang, L., Sung, Y., & Antonescu, C. R. (2018). Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans with a novel col6a3‐pdgfd fusion gene and apparent predilection for breast. Genes, Chromosomes and Cancer, 57(9), 437–445. https://doi.org/10.1002/gcc.22663
Summary:: This study investigates dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP), which typically occurs in adults and has a slight male predilection. The characteristic histopathologic features include storiform architecture, infiltrative growth within subcutaneous adipose tissue, and immunoreactivity for CD34. Most cases of DFSP harbor a COL1A1-PDGFB fusion gene. The study identifies an index patient with a novel COL6A3-PDGFD fusion gene in DFSP.

Citation: Gimeno‐Ribes, M., Toll, A., Garcia, A., & Giavedoni, P. (2023). Usefulness of high‐frequency doppler ultrasound in dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans. Journal of Ultrasound in Medicine, 42(9), 2171–2173. https://doi.org/10.1002/jum.16217
Summary:: The study discusses the use of imaging techniques such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) and high-frequency ultrasound of the skin (HFUS) for assessing DFSP. While MRI can accurately identify tumors limited to the subcutaneous tissue, its precision diminishes for tumors located in areas such as the upper trunk, head, and neck. It often underestimates lateral extension and provides uncertain images in cases of residual tumor after surgical excision.

Citation: Walsh NM, Cerroni L. Merkel cell carcinoma: A review. J Cutan Pathol. 2021; 48(3): 411–421. https://doi.org/10.1111/cup.13910

Summary:: This is an epidemiological study to understand the characteristics of population health in terms of Microsystic adnexal carcinoma. IT uses the SEER which is a national database of 18 cancer registeries. It looks at the number of cases, incidence, race/ethnicity, location of primary tumors, staging, and whether it was the patient's first malignancy. As such, it's a mass population health study to understand the demographic characteristics of who gets this type of cancer.
